poster_metadata.display_title:
Changing Currents:
Life, Faith, and Survival Across

palette_source.notes: Palette extracted from spreadsheet per workflow. Note: proof PDF map appears to use a different color assignment; see validation_and_todos.

legend.title: ASIA HIGH AND LOW LEGEND
general_rules: Most metrics use green icons for the “high/favorable” end and orange icons for the “low/unfavorable” end.
Exception: “Lowest Crime Rate” is favorable at the low numeric end; green indicates lowest crime and orange indicates highest crime.
“Average Household Size” uses a distinct color pair (purple vs blue) to indicate largest vs smallest households (descriptive rather than good/bad).

capital_marker.description: Small circular markers with a white cross appear across countries (likely capitals).
capital_marker.color_note: Markers appear in orange/red on the proof map.

assets.description: Central Asia map with per-country palette fills and country labels (embedded in proof PDF).

featurettes.title: Origination of Major Religions
featurettes.body_text:
Long ago, in lands stretching from the Middle East to India, some of the world’s major religions were born. Judaism, Christianity, and Islam arose in the deserts and cities near the Mediterranean Sea. Hinduism and Buddhism took root in India’s rich landscapes, while Sikhism began in the Punjab region.

These faiths shaped how people live, think, and come together. Their ideas spread across the Earth through travel, trade, and teaching, inspiring millions today. By understanding where these religions started and what they share—like respect, kindness, and hope—we can better appreciate the diverse beliefs that guide so many lives.

assets.description: Row of icons representing Judaism, Islam, Christianity, Hinduism, Sikhism, and Buddhism (as shown at top of the featurette).
Illustration of diverse people representing multiple faiths (top-right of the featurette).
Photo of a holy site (Western Wall / Jerusalem) used in the Religions featurette.

hyperlinks.anchor_text: holy site, such as the Wester

assets.description: Referenced in Asia Featurettes.docx: map showing where major religions began. Not clearly present as a standalone map in the proof poster; included as a dependency placeholder.

charts.title: Where major religions began (map)

data_table.origin_site_example: Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem

charts.layout_notes: Featurettes.docx calls for a map + symbols chart. Proof poster shows a symbols strip and a faint world map background, but not a dedicated origin map.

chart_spec.iconography_notes: Symbols shown: Star of David (Judaism), Crescent and star (Islam), Cross (Christianity), Om (Hinduism), Khanda (Sikhism), Dharma wheel (Buddhism).

featurettes.title:
India –
A Land of Contrasts Between
Rich and Poor
featurettes.body_text:
India is a land of shining skyscrapers, busy tech hubs, and world-famous business leaders. Yet not far from these modern marvels, you’ll find families who struggle with old tools on small farms or cramped neighborhoods without clean water or electricity.

This big gap between rich and poor comes from a long history and fast changes. Today, India is working hard to share its growing wealth more fairly. New schools, better jobs, and smarter farming methods aim to lift people out of poverty. As India grows, so does the hope that everyone can enjoy a better life.

assets.description: Photo of a luxury high-rise/skyscraper (Antilia Tower, Mumbai) used to represent wealth.
Photo of a dense, crowded neighborhood/slum area used to contrast wealth and poverty.
Photo of rural farmers working in a field (agriculture / livelihoods).

hyperlinks.anchor_text: Rural farmers working in a field

assets.description: Referenced in Asia Featurettes.docx: map showing regions with higher incomes and those with lower incomes. Not present in the proof poster PDF; included as a dependency placeholder.

charts.title: India income regions (higher vs. lower incomes)
charts.layout_notes: Featurettes.docx calls for a government-data income/wealth map, but the proof poster uses a photo-based contrast layout without a visible map.

featurettes.title:
China’s Changing Population –
A Story of Growth and Change
featurettes.body_text:
Imagine a country growing so fast that leaders once encouraged families to have as many children as possible. That was China after 1949. Soon, the population soared. But too many people meant too few resources, so China introduced the One-Child Policy. Families could only have one child, hoping to slow down the rapid growth.

Over time, this led to more boys than girls, since many parents wanted sons. Today, China faces fewer young people, more elderly, and a changing future. The rules have loosened, allowing more children per family, but raising kids is expensive, and many parents still choose smaller families. China now works to balance its population, care for the elderly, and value all children equally.

assets.description: Photo of a Chinese family walking in a city street (top of China featurette).

hyperlinks.anchor_text: A modern Chinese family strolling in a busy city stree

assets.description: Line chart titled “Midyear Population vs. Year” showing China’s midyear population over time.
Line chart titled “Crude Birth Rate (per 1000) vs. Year” showing China’s crude birth rate over time.

featurettes.title:
Japan –
Living on The Ring of Fire
featurettes.body_text:
Japan sits on the “Ring of Fire,” where giant pieces of Earth’s crust meet and shake. Earthquakes, volcanoes, and tsunamis are part of daily life here.

Instead of fearing these forces, Japan prepares. Buildings sway safely instead of breaking. Alarms on phones give early warnings. Students practice drills so they know what to do when the ground trembles.

In 2011, a huge earthquake and tsunami hit Japan, causing big problems at a nuclear power plant. Since then, safety has improved, and communities stand ready to help each other.

Japan’s story shows that by planning, learning, and working together, people can thrive— even in nature’s most active neighborhood.

assets.description: Photo showing the aftermath/result of a tsunami (top of Japan featurette).

hyperlinks.anchor_text: Showing the result of a tsunami

assets.description: Diagram explaining how Japanese buildings resist earthquakes (three approaches illustrated).
Photo of a school earthquake drill (students practicing safety procedures).

charts.title: How Japanese buildings resist earthquakes

elements.label: Vibration Control (Seishin)
elements.description: Uses dampers to reduce sway and vibration.

elements.label: Base Isolation (Menshin)
elements.description: Isolates the building from ground motion using bearings/isolators.

charts.layout_notes: Displayed as a small three-panel illustration at the lower right of the Japan featurette.

chart_spec.iconography_notes: Diagram is conceptual; no quantitative data table.

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Arsenic contamination in groundwater
supplemental_stats_for_app.stat_text: Bangladesh: Asia Stats.docx notes that an estimated ~20 million people are exposed to arsenic-contaminated groundwater, described as one of the largest mass poisonings in history.

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Disaster-related volunteerism
supplemental_stats_for_app.stat_text: Japan: Asia Stats.docx notes that after the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, over 1 million volunteers joined recovery efforts—highlighting community response during crises.

source.section_title: Percentage of Population Engaged in Volunteer Activities or Community Service

supplemental_stats_for_app.title: Education pressure
supplemental_stats_for_app.stat_text: South Korea: Asia Stats.docx highlights intense academic pressure and long study hours, raising concerns about student stress and well-being.

source.section_title: Percentage of Population with Higher Education Degrees

issues.description: Palette extracted from Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx (stats palette sheet) does not include Papua New Guinea, which appears on the proof map (bottom-right).
issues.recommended_action: Add Papua New Guinea to stats palette (country name + hex) or confirm whether it should be included/excluded from the Asia map.

issues.description: The proof PDF map appears to use a different per-country color assignment than the hex palette listed in the spreadsheet (e.g., sampled Russia fill in proof appears orange, while spreadsheet lists a blue hex for Russia).
issues.recommended_action: Confirm which version is authoritative (spreadsheet palette vs. proof PDF). If proof is final, provide an updated palette table matching the proof.

issues.description: Several URLs in Asia Featurettes.docx appear truncated with ellipses (e.g., some Alamy/Wikipedia/AP News links and the reddit preview link).
issues.recommended_action: Replace truncated URLs with full, direct asset URLs for reliable downstream use.

issues.description: India and Religions featurettes in the proof poster are primarily photo/illustration based and do not clearly include the map/chart elements described in Featurettes.docx; placeholders were added in this schema.
issues.recommended_action: Confirm whether those maps/charts are intended for a later revision or app-only experience; provide final chart assets/specs if required.

issues.description: No “graphs stuff.docx” was provided, so iconization math/unit definitions for charts (if any) are not captured beyond what is visible in proof and spreadsheet tables.
issues.recommended_action: Provide graphs stuff.docx if icon math or chart construction rules are needed for automation.
